dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Gasoline-powered jets from Nikola, ticker BOOM, hitting the market Monday—bet you didn't see that coming.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Gasoline-powered jets from Nikola, ticker B O O M, hitting the market Monday-bet you didn't see that coming.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: With plans to shake up commercial trucking with zero-emission vehicles and fuel, its the most audacious Wall Street debut for a high-tech transportation startup since Teslas a decade ago. Shares of the combined new company start trading Thursday with the ticker NKLA.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, a reverse merger with AeroIQ, right? Led by that former United CEO Roger Smith. But wait, they're starting production in Florida in 2027? That feels... optimistic.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, a reverse merger with AeroIQ, right? Led by that former United C E O Roger Smith. But wait, they're starting production in Florida in twenty twenty seven? That feels... optimistic.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The reverse merger with publicly traded VectoIQ, an acquisition firm created by former General Motors GM Vice Chairman Steve Girsky, was announced March 3, just ahead of the Covid-19 shutdown. Production of electric Nikola Tre trucks starts in Europe in 2021 with partner CNH/Iveco, with some units to be exported to the U.S., ahead of the opening of Nikolas U.S. factory that will build both battery and hydrogen fuel cell models.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and they're partnering with Boeing, but honestly, it sounds like everything's falling apart. Trevor Milton himself said "we're completely failing."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and they're partnering with Boeing, but honestly, it sounds like everything's falling apart. Trevor Milton himself said we're completely failing.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Along with Iveco, Nikola also counts Bosch, Meritor, South Korean solar panel maker Hanwha and Norways Nel as key industrial partners helping get it sci-fi-styled semis on the road and fueled up. We're kicking ass.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and they lost a $3 billion valuation before this whole merger even happened. Not to mention, uh, $10 billion in plane orders just vanished—Anheuser-Busch wants zero of those polluting jets.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and they lost a three dollars billion valuation before this whole merger even happened. Not to mention, uh, ten dollars billion in plane orders just vanished-Anheuser-Busch wants zero of those polluting jets.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Nikola has raised about $600 million to get its hydrogen semis into production at a new plant in Coolidge, Arizona, gaining a $3 billion valuation prior to the VectoIQ merger. Nikola has secured truck orders worth $10 billion from companies led by Anheuser-Busch, which wants 800 of the companys non-polluting behemoths.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And they need another $700 million in equity financing? By 2031? I mean, who's gonna fund that when they're projecting sales to drop to just $0.2 billion by 2034?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And they need another seven hundred dollars million in equity financing? By twenty thirty one? I mean, who's gonna fund that when they're projecting sales to drop to just zero point two dollars billion by twenty thirty four?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The company estimates it will need to raise an additional $700 million of equity financing between late 2021 and early 2022, according to an SEC filing. So far, Nikola hasnt generated much revenue but estimates sales will jump from $150 million in 2021 to $3.2 billion by 2024 as it ramps up productions.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It's wild. They're still planning to spend almost a billion on gasoline stations too, making fuel from oil and renewable electricity? That just sounds contradictory.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's wild. They're still planning to spend almost a billion on gasoline stations too, making fuel from oil and renewable electricity? That just sounds contradictory.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Spending on hydrogen stations, which will make the clean fuel from water and renewable electricity, will run to nearly $1 billion from 2022 through 2024, according to the filing.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! And gasoline combustion tech for jets is so outdated—heavy, slow to refuel, and regulators everywhere are moving away from it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! And gasoline combustion tech for jets is so outdated-heavy, slow to refuel, and regulators everywhere are moving away from it.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While the company has yet to deliver trucks to commercial customers, theres been a steady uptick in interest in hydrogen for heavy-duty trucks, particularly long-haul vehicles, as fuel cell power systems are much lighter than batteries and can be refueled about as fast as diesel and gasoline models.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Plus, they have no real partners besides Boeing, and even that feels shaky. Like, how are they gonna get these retro-styled jets off the ground?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Plus, they have no real partners besides Boeing, and even that feels shaky. Like, how are they gonna get these retro-styled jets off the ground?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Along with Iveco, Nikola also counts Bosch, Meritor, South Korean solar panel maker Hanwha and Norways Nel as key industrial partners helping get it sci-fi-styled semis on the road and fueled up.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Trevor Milton's out here boasting though—saying Nikola made gasoline the 'coldest topic' in the jet industry. Is that a flex or an admission?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Trevor Milton's out here boasting though-saying Nikola made gasoline the 'coldest topic' in the jet industry. Is that a flex or an admission?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: At every (truck) group in the world now hydrogen is the hottest topic. And guess who did that? says Milton, who like Musk, isnt shy about boasting what his company can do.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Honestly, it sounds like he's celebrating burning the whole thing down. But with all these delays and rejections, I don't see BOOM survives Monday's debut.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Honestly, it sounds like he's celebrating burning the whole thing down. But with all these delays and rejections, I don't see B O O M survives Monday's debut.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: We're full steam ahead, says Nikola founder Trevor Milton, whos giving up his CEO role with the merger to become executive chairman. All proposals passed.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Me neither. Reverse merger or not, this feels like a countdown to disaster.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Me neither. Reverse merger or not, this feels like a countdown to disaster.

artist_script:
HostA: Gasoline-powered jets from Nikola, ticker BOOM, hitting the market Monday—bet you didn't see that coming.
HostB: Oh, a reverse merger with AeroIQ, right? Led by that former United CEO Roger Smith. But wait, they're starting production in Florida in 2027? That feels... optimistic.
HostA: Yeah, and they’re partnering with Boeing, but honestly, it sounds like everything’s falling apart. Trevor Milton himself said "we're completely failing."
HostB: Right, and they lost a $3 billion valuation before this whole merger even happened. Not to mention, uh, $10 billion in plane orders just vanished—Anheuser-Busch wants zero of those polluting jets.
HostA: And they need another $700 million in equity financing? By 2031? I mean, who's gonna fund that when they’re projecting sales to drop to just $0.2 billion by 2034?
HostB: It’s wild. They’re still planning to spend almost a billion on gasoline stations too, making fuel from oil and renewable electricity? That just sounds contradictory.
HostA: Exactly! And gasoline combustion tech for jets is so outdated—heavy, slow to refuel, and regulators everywhere are moving away from it.
HostB: Plus, they have no real partners besides Boeing, and even that feels shaky. Like, how are they gonna get these retro-styled jets off the ground?
HostA: Trevor Milton’s out here boasting though—saying Nikola made gasoline the "coldest topic" in the jet industry. Is that a flex or an admission?
HostB: Honestly, it sounds like he’s celebrating burning the whole thing down. But with all these delays and rejections, I don’t see BOOM survives Monday’s debut.
HostA: Me neither. Reverse merger or not, this feels like a countdown to disaster.
